column5: é (biÃ n)This word is used to indicate the completion of an action or the occurrence of an event throughout a certain area or period of time. It is often used with verbs to indicate the completion of an action throughout a specified area or period.æ—¶å€™ (shÃ­hou)This word refers to a specific point in time or a period of time during which something occurs. It is used to indicate the timing or occurrence of events.è¶Ÿ (tÃ ng)This word is a measure word used for trips, journeys, or rounds of actions. It is used to count the number of times an action is performed, particularly for trips or journeys.å€ (bÃ¨i)This word means "times" or "multiplied by" and is used to indicate multiplication or a multiple of a certain quantity.æ¬¡ (cÃ¬)This word is a measure word used to count the number of times an action or event occurs.æ—¶é—´ (shÃ­jiÄn)This word specifically refers to time as a duration or period, and is used to indicate the length or duration of events or actions.In summary, é (biÃ n) is used to indicate the completion of an action throughout a certain area or period of time, while æ—¶å€™ (shÃ­hou), è¶Ÿ (tÃ ng), å€ (bÃ¨i), æ¬¡ (cÃ¬), and æ—¶é—´ (shÃ­jiÄn) have their own specific usages related to timing, frequency, or duration.

column3: to feel happy/to rejoice/to have a great time/to make fun of sb
column5: å¼€å¿ƒ (kÄixÄ«n)This is the most commonly used term for "happy" in general.å¿«ä¹ (kuÃ ilÃ¨)This word can only really be used in expressions like "Happy New Year"/"Happy Birthday"/"Happy Christmas" etc.é«˜å…´ (gÄoxÃ¬ng)This is almost the same meaning as å¼€å¿ƒ, but ä¸é«˜å…´ carries more of a connotation of being angry than being unhappy.æ„‰å¿« (yÃºkuÃ i)This is really not very different from å¿«ä¹, but it is used for things that are smaller in scale, like "happy weekend", "happy journey" etc.å¹¸ç¦ (xÃ¬ngfÃº)This refers to a very deep, stable, sense of happiness, typically lasting a long time.For example, if you are saying you are feeling happy right now, å¼€å¿ƒ (kÄixÄ«n) or é«˜å…´ (gÄoxÃ¬ng) are the right ones to use. column5: å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬)This word is used to express a contrast or contradiction between two clauses or sentences. It can be translated as "but," and is used to indicate unexpected or contradictory information.è€Œ (Ã©r), ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), å´ (quÃ¨)These words also express contrast or contradiction, but each has its own specific usage. è€Œ (Ã©r) is used to connect two clauses or sentences, similar to "and" or "while." ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²) is used to introduce a contrasting idea or to downplay the significance of the preceding statement. ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r) is more formal and literary, conveying a sense of transition or contrast between two ideas, similar to "however" or "nevertheless." å´ (quÃ¨) is used to indicate a contrast or contradiction, similar to "but," "yet," or "however."In summary, å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬) is used to express a contrast or contradiction, while è€Œ (Ã©r), ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), and å´ (quÃ¨) have their own specific nuances and usage.

column5: å´ (quÃ¨)This word is used to indicate a contrast or contradiction between two clauses or sentences. It can be translated as "but," "yet," "however," or "nevertheless," and is used to express unexpected or contradictory information.å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬), ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬), è€Œ (Ã©r), å€’ (dÃ o), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²)These are synonyms for expressing contrast, contradiction, or concession, but each has its own specific usage. å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬) is used to convey a contrast or contradiction, similar to "but" or "however." ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬) means "still" or "yet," and is used to indicate that a situation or condition persists. è€Œ (Ã©r) is used to connect two clauses or ideas, similar to "and" or "while." å€’ (dÃ o) is used to express a contrast or unexpected outcome. ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r) is also used to indicate a contrast or contradiction, similar to "however" or "nevertheless." ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²) is used to introduce a contrasting or concessive idea.While å´ (quÃ¨) can be used to indicate a contrast within the same sentence, å¯æ˜¯ (kÄ›shÃ¬), ä»ç„¶ (rÃ©nglÃ¬), è€Œ (Ã©r), å€’ (dÃ o), ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r), and ä¸è¿‡ (bÃ¹guÃ²) have their own specific nuances and usage. Additionally, ç„¶è€Œ (rÃ¡n'Ã©r) is more formal and literary compared to å´ (quÃ¨).

column5: è¶Ÿ (tÃ ng)This word is a measure word used for trips, journeys, or rounds of an activity. It is specifically used to count the number of times an action is performed, such as going on a trip or completing a round of an activity.é (biÃ n), æ—¶å€™ (shÃ­hou), æ—¶é—´ (shÃ­jiÄn)These words are not direct synonyms for è¶Ÿ (tÃ ng) as they have different meanings and usage. é (biÃ n) is used to indicate the completion of an action or activity throughout, such as reading a book cover to cover. æ—¶å€™ (shÃ­hou) means "time" in the sense of a specific point in time or a period, and æ—¶é—´ (shÃ­jiÄn) refers to the concept of time as a duration or interval.For example, you can use è¶Ÿ (tÃ ng) to say "I have been to Beijing three times," but you wouldn't use é (biÃ n), æ—¶å€™ (shÃ­hou), or æ—¶é—´ (shÃ­jiÄn) in this context.
